rewritten_query: It seems like the user is asking about how to filter messages, but the context of what exactly they want to filter is not provided in this utterance. To make it a standalone question, we need to add the necessary context. Here's a possible way to reword it: {"class": "non-standalone", "reworded version": "How can I filter messages in this context?"}.
agent_response:
Based on the provided document, you can filter messages in Watson Assistant by Search user statements, Intents, Entities, and Last n days.

1. Search user statements - Type a word in the search bar. This searches the users' inputs, but not your assistant's replies.
2. Intents - Select the drop-down menu and type an intent in the input field, or choose from the populated list. You can select more than one intent, which filters the results using any of the selected intents, including Irrelevant.
3. Entities - Select the drop-down menu and type an entity name in the input field, or choose from the populated list. You can select more than one entity, which filters the results by any of the selected entities. If you filter by intent and entity, your results will include the messages that have both values. You can also filter for results with No entities found.

Messages might take some time to update. Allow at least 30 minutes after a user's interaction with your assistant before attempting to filter for that content.

If you want to filter conversations in the Watson Assistant Analytics dashboard, you can do so by Actions, Keyword, Recognition, and Search.

1. Actions - Select specific actions. You can choose one or more actions to review.
2. Keyword - Search by session ID or for specific key terms, phrases, or words in the conversations.
3. Recognition - Choose between recognized or unrecognized user questions or requests.
4. Search - Choose between requests that initiated a search or requests that produced no search results.

The Actions and Keyword filters always appear at the top of the page. To show the Recognition and Search filters, click the Additional filters icon.

If you have activated dialog in your assistant, the Actions filter is replaced by a Topics filter.

If you search for a specific session ID, enclose your search in quotation marks to ensure you receive an exact match on the full ID with its numbers and hyphen characters, for example: "9015ab9a-2e13-4627-ae33-4179b1125cb5".

To explore individual conversations in detail, you can click on any of the utterances or conversation time stamps.

original_query: What are the advantages and disadvantages of Immutable data Storage?
rewritten_query: What are the advantages and disadvantages of Immutable data Storage?
agent_response:
Based on the provided document, here are some advantages and disadvantages of Immutable Object Storage:

Advantages:
1. Data Integrity: Immutable Object Storage maintains data integrity in a WORM (Write-Once-Read-Many) manner, ensuring that objects can't be modified until the end of their retention period and the removal of any legal holds.
2. Long-term Data Retention: This feature is useful for any user that needs long-term data retention in their environment, including industries like Financial, Healthcare, Media content archives, and anyone looking to prevent privileged modification or deletion of objects or documents.
3. Compliance: Immutable Object Storage can help organizations that deal with financial records management, such as broker-dealer transactions, to store data in a non-rewritable and non-erasable format, which is often a requirement for compliance.

Disadvantages:
1. Limited Availability: Immutable Object Storage is available in certain regions only.
2. Pricing: It requires a Standard pricing plan.
3. Incompatibility with Aspera High-Speed Transfer: It isn't possible to use Aspera high-speed transfer with buckets with a retention policy.
4. No Automatic Deletion: Immutable Object Storage does not support automatic deletion of files after a defined period.
5. Legal Holds: Any legal holds must be manually removed for the retention policy to expire.

Please note that this response is based on the provided document and the specific product or service might have additional advantages or disadvantages.

rewritten_query: I want to know about creating an Enterprise account in IBM Cloud.
agent_response:
It seems like the user has stopped asking questions and mentioned the word "Enterprise". I will provide information about creating an enterprise in IBM Cloud based on the provided document.

Creating an enterprise involves a few steps:

1. Choose the account that you want to use as the base for the enterprise. This account will be the parent account in the enterprise hierarchy.
2. Ensure you have the necessary permissions: you must be the account owner or have the Administrator role on the Billing account management service in the account.
3. Create the enterprise from the account. Once created, the account will become the root account in the enterprise hierarchy and can't be removed. Billing will be managed by the enterprise, but users and resources in the account will remain unaffected.
4. To create the enterprise, go to the IBM Cloud console, navigate to Manage > Enterprise, and click Create. Enter the enterprise name, domain, review the account impact information, and click Create.

After creating the enterprise, you can access the enterprise dashboard and set up an enterprise structure with account groups. Account groups help organize related accounts in your enterprise hierarchy. You can create account groups from the Enterprise dashboard in the IBM Cloud console by clicking Accounts > Create. Provide a name for the account group, select a contact if needed, choose a parent account group or leave it as the root, and click Create. Remember that account groups can't be deleted or moved from where you create them.

To create a new tier in your enterprise hierarchy, create new account groups within an existing account group. Move accounts that are already in the enterprise into the account group, or import or create accounts within it.

rewritten_query: I need assistance with something.
agent_response:
It seems like the user has mentioned the word "Support". I can provide information on how to connect customers with support in the context of the assistant.

You can build the dialog of your assistant to recognize when customers need help that cannot be provided by the assistant. Add logic that can connect your customers to professional support. Your solutions might include:

1. A toll-free phone number to a call center that is manned by human agents
2. An online support ticket form that customers fill out and submit
3. A service desk solution that is configured to work with your custom client application. The built-in Zendesk and Salesforce integrations aren’t supported.

You can design the dialog to recognize customer requests for help and add an intent that understands the customer request. Then, add a dialog branch that handles the request. For example:

Intent name | Intent user example 1 | Intent user example 2 | Response from dialog node that conditions on intent
--- | --- | --- | ---
call\_support | How do I reach support? | What's your toll-free number? | Call 1-800-555-0123 to reach a call center agent at any time.
support\_ticket | How do I get help? | Who can help me with an issue I'm having? | Go to [Support Center](https://example.com/support) and open a support ticket.

For phone integration, you can also add support for initiating a transfer to human agents when a user asks to speak to someone or when the conversation broaches a topic that is sensitive in nature.

original_query: I cannot get select query to work, what steps should I take?
rewritten_query: I cannot get select query to work, what steps should I take?
agent_response:
Here are some steps you can take to troubleshoot your SELECT query:

1. Check the syntax of your query to ensure it follows the general structure of an SQL query statement.
2. Verify that the table and column names in your query are spelled correctly and exist in your database.
3. Make sure you have the necessary permissions to access the data in the table.
4. If your query is a SELECT statement, check that you have specified the correct input objects (tables or partitions) after the FROM keyword.
5. If the input objects are in a text format such as CSV or JSON, make sure they are not compressed with gzip or bzip2, as this can cause performance issues.
6. If the input objects are in CSV format and a delimiter other than the default comma is used, make sure you have specified the delimiter using the FIELDS TERMINATED BY option of the STORED AS clause.
7. If the input objects are in a binary format such as ORC, Parquet, or AVRO, make sure you have specified the format using the STORED AS clause after the FROM keyword.

If you're still having trouble, you can refer to the Data Engine documentation and the IBM Cloud SQL Query blog for more information on using Data Engine and running SELECT queries.

rewritten_query: How can I enhance or optimize my query?
agent_response:
Here are some general tips to improve your query performance:

1. **Limiting the number of documents returned**: You can use the `limit` parameter in your query to only return a specific number of documents. This can help improve performance by reducing the amount of data that needs to be processed and returned.

2. **Using indexes**: Indexes can help improve query performance by allowing the database to quickly locate and retrieve the data that you're looking for. In the Cloudant documentation provided, it's recommended to use the `explain` feature to see which index is being selected for each query and to create meaningful indexes on fixed attributes.

3. **Reducing the complexity of your query**: Queries with a lot of aggregations, operators, or counts can be more complex and take longer to process. If possible, try to simplify your query by reducing the number of aggregations, operators, or counts.

4. **Limiting the fields returned**: Only retrieving the fields that you need can help improve query performance by reducing the amount of data that needs to be processed and returned.

5. **Using features like passage retrieval and relevancy training judiciously**: These features can enhance query results, but they can also impact performance. Make sure you're only using them when necessary and that you're adjusting parameters like `passages.fields` and the number of top-level fields to minimize their impact on performance.

6. **Using the filter parameter for simple queries**: If you're running a simple query, especially on a small data set, using the filter parameter can be faster than using the query parameter, as it excludes any documents that don't mention the query content without returning results in order of relevance.

If you provide more specific details about your query, I may be able to offer more tailored advice.

rewritten_query: Can you give more details about the query API?
agent_response:
The Query API is a RESTful API provided by IBM Watson Query for interacting with a database instance. It allows you to access and manage data using the supported Watson Query SDKs, such as the Go SDK and the Java SDK.

The Query API provides endpoints for various operations, including querying data, creating database objects, administering the service, and monitoring the system. The API reference for the Query API can be found in the IBM Cloud documentation.

The Query API supports the 'passages' parameter, which can be used to return a set of the most relevant passages from the documents in your collection. This feature is supported only on private collections and not in the Watson Discovery News collection. The passages parameter currently returns a maximum of three (3) passages from any given document in the collection.

Additionally, the Query API also supports the 'sort' parameter, which enables you to specify a comma-separated list of fields in the document to sort on. This feature can help you to sort and retrieve data based on specific fields and values.

It's important to note that specifying the passages parameter can reduce performance as a result of increased processing to extract passages. With larger environments, the performance impact can be lessened. Additionally, the passages parameter returns a maximum of 10 results, and the number of returned results cannot be changed.

If you need more information or have further questions about the Query API, you can refer to the IBM Cloud documentation and the IBM Cloud SQL Query blog for more information on using Data Engine and running queries.

rewritten_query: Can I address my storage space limits? How can I add or delete storage?
agent_response:
Yes, you can address your storage space limits by taking several actions. First, you can delete snapshot versions of any models that you do not expect to need to revert to. You can also delete any models that you do not need. If your models are too important to delete, you can consider upgrading your plan to one that provides a larger allotment of storage space. After removing models or model versions, wait an hour before retrying the action that resulted in the error message, as it can take up to an hour for the storage space that you freed up to be available for use.

If you have a Premium or Standard account and the Admin role is assigned to you, you can set a storage limit on the Service Details page in Knowledge Studio to manage your monthly bill.

To add or delete storage using IBM Cloud Object Storage, follow the instructions in the provided documents. This includes setting a list of authorized IP addresses using a legacy firewall and removing any IP address restrictions using a legacy firewall. Additionally, you can use the Satellite storage dashboard to delete a storage configuration.

If you're referring to storage limitations in the context of IBM Cloud SQL Query, you can improve query performance by limiting the number of documents returned, using indexes, reducing the complexity of your query, limiting the fields returned, using features like passage retrieval and relevancy training judiciously, and using the filter parameter for simple queries.

rewritten_query: Could you provide more details about what data lakes are?
agent_response: A data lake is an approach to storing data in its native format for organizational use. It involves storing data in a centralized repository, such as Object Storage, where it can be accessed, analyzed, and shared by different users and applications. By combining Object Storage and Data Engine, data analysts can query data where it lies using Structured Query Language (SQL). Data lakes allow organizations to store large volumes of structured and unstructured data, making it easily accessible for analysis and insights.

If you're looking for information on how to define a query in SQL, I would refer you to the steps I provided earlier for troubleshooting a SELECT query, as those steps include best practices for defining and structuring a query in SQL.
how can I improve query

Here are some general tips to improve your query performance:

1.
**Limiting the number of documents returned**: You can use the `limit` parameter in your query to only return a specific number of documents.
This can help improve performance by reducing the amount of data that needs to be processed and returned.
**Using indexes**: Indexes can help improve query performance by allowing the database to quickly locate and retrieve the data that you're looking for.
In the Cloudant documentation provided, it's recommended to use the `explain` feature to see which index is being selected for each query and to create meaningful indexes on fixed attributes.
**Reducing the complexity of your query**: Queries with a lot of aggregations, operators, or counts can be more complex and take longer to process.
If possible, try to simplify your query by reducing the number of aggregations, operators, or counts.
**Limiting the fields returned**: Only retrieving the fields that you need can help improve query performance by reducing the amount of data that needs to be processed and returned.
**Using features like passage retrieval and relevancy training judiciously**: These features can enhance query results, but they can also impact performance.
Make sure you're only using them when necessary and that you're adjusting parameters like `passages.fields` and the number of top-level fields to minimize their impact on performance.

**Using the filter parameter for simple queries**: If you're running a simple query, especially on a small data set, using the filter parameter can be faster than using the query parameter, as it excludes any documents that don't mention the query content without returning results in order of relevance.

can you give more details about the query API?
The Query API is a RESTful API provided by IBM Watson Query for interacting with a database instance.
It allows you to access and manage data using the supported Watson Query SDKs, such as the Go SDK and the Java SDK.
The Query API provides endpoints for various operations, including querying data, creating database objects, administering the service, and monitoring the system.
The API reference for the Query API can be found in the IBM Cloud documentation.
The Query API supports the 'passages' parameter, which can be used to return a set of the most relevant passages from the documents in your collection.
This feature is supported only on private collections and not in the Watson Discovery News collection.
The passages parameter currently returns a maximum of three (3) passages from any given document in the collection.
Additionally, the Query API also supports the 'sort' parameter, which enables you to specify a comma-separated list of fields in the document to sort on.
This feature can help you to sort and retrieve data based on specific fields and values.
It's important to note that specifying the passages parameter can reduce performance as a result of increased processing to extract passages.
With larger environments, the performance impact can be lessened.
Additionally, the passages parameter returns a maximum of 10 results, and the number of returned results cannot be changed.

If you need more information or have further questions about the Query API, you can refer to the IBM Cloud documentation and the IBM Cloud SQL Query blog for more information on using Data Engine and running queries.
Can I address my storage space limits? how can I add or delete storage?
Yes, you can address your storage space limits by taking several actions.
First, you can delete snapshot versions of any models that you do not expect to need to revert to.
You can also delete any models that you do not need.
If your models are too important to delete, you can consider upgrading your plan to one that provides a larger allotment of storage space.

After removing models or model versions, wait an hour before retrying the action that resulted in the error message, as it can take up to an hour for the storage space that you freed up to be available for use.
If you have a Premium or Standard account and the Admin role is assigned to you, you can set a storage limit on the Service Details page in Knowledge Studio to manage your monthly bill.
To add or delete storage using IBM Cloud Object Storage, follow the instructions in the provided documents.
This includes setting a list of authorized IP addresses using a legacy firewall and removing any IP address restrictions using a legacy firewall.
Additionally, you can use the Satellite storage dashboard to delete a storage configuration.

If you're referring to storage limitations in the context of IBM Cloud SQL Query, you can improve query performance by limiting the number of documents returned, using indexes, reducing the complexity of your query, limiting the fields returned, using features like passage retrieval and relevancy training judiciously, and using the filter parameter for simple queries.
what is Data lakes
A data lake is an approach to storing data in its native format for organizational use.
It involves storing data in a centralized repository, such as Object Storage, where it can be accessed, analyzed, and shared by different users and applications.
By combining Object Storage and Data Engine, data analysts can query data where it lies using Structured Query Language (SQL).
Data lakes allow organizations to store large volumes of structured and unstructured data, making it easily accessible for analysis and insights.

rewritten_query: Can you clarify how to create a schema or tables?
agent_response:
To create a schema or tables, you can follow these general steps:

1. Log in to the watsonx.data console.
2. From the navigation menu, select Data manager.
3. Select the engine from the Engine drop-down. Catalogs that are associated with the selected engine are listed.
4. Select a schema under a catalog where you want to create a table.
5. Click the overflow menu of the selected schema and select one of the following options:
* If you want to create a table from scratch, select "Create table".
* If you want to import a file to create a table, select "Create table from a file".
6. Follow the steps provided in the documentation to complete the process of creating the schema or table.

If you are using IBM Cloud SQL Query, you can create a table in the catalog using the CREATE TABLE statement, as follows:

CREATE TABLE <table\_name>
(column1 datatype, column2 datatype, ...)
USING <storage\_format>
LOCATION <object\_storage\_uri>

Note: You will need to replace <table\_name>, <column1>, <column2>, <datatype>, <storage\_format>, and <object\_storage\_uri> with the appropriate values for your use case.

rewritten_query: Use IBM Cloudant Query.
agent_response:
Sure, I can help you with that! IBM Cloudant Query is a powerful feature of IBM Cloudant that allows you to query your data using a flexible query language based on Apache Lucene. Here are some steps to get started with IBM Cloudant Query:

1. Define an index: Before you can query your data using IBM Cloudant Query, you need to define an index. An index is a data structure that is optimized for fast search and retrieval of data. You can define an index using a design document, which is a JSON document that contains the index definition. The index definition specifies the fields that you want to index and the parameters for each field.
2. Query the data: Once you have defined an index, you can query the data using the _find endpoint. The query language is based on Apache Lucene, and it allows you to search for data using various operators and functions. You can search for data based on exact matches, regular expressions, ranges, and more.
3. Retrieve the results: When you query the data using IBM Cloudant Query, you can retrieve the results in various formats, including JSON, XML, and CSV. You can also specify the number of documents to return, the sort order, and other parameters.

Here's an example of how to use IBM Cloudant Query to search for documents by author and year:

GET /{database}/_design/{ddoc}/_search/{index}?q="author:Dickens AND year:1840"

In this example, {database} is the name of the database that contains the documents, {ddoc} is the name of the design document that contains the index definition, and {index} is the name of the index. The q parameter specifies the query, which searches for documents where the author is Dickens and the year is 1840.

Keep in mind that IBM Cloudant Query is just one of the many features of IBM Cloudant, and there are many other ways to interact with your data using the IBM Cloudant API. If you have any specific questions or issues, feel free to ask!

rewritten_query: What does Vulnerability Advisor scan and what are its functions?
agent_response: Vulnerability Advisor scans images for security issues and provides an evaluation report based on security practices specific to IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service. It checks for vulnerable packages in images using supported operating systems and provides links to relevant security notices about the vulnerability. Packages that contain known vulnerability issues are displayed in the scan results. In addition, it collects, stores, and processes certain information to operate and improve the service. However, it does not scan encrypted images.

rewritten_query: How do version 3 and version 4 of Vulnerability Advisor differ?
agent_response:
Vulnerability Advisor version 4 has some differences in behavior compared to version 3. For instance, in version 4, the image is indexed the first time it is pushed, and the vulnerability assessment is calculated every time Vulnerability Advisor is queried about that image. Additionally, the supported Docker base images that Vulnerability Advisor checks for vulnerable packages have been updated in version 4. However, version 4 only supports releases of platforms that are currently supported by the vendor of that platform. For a detailed comparison of the supported Docker base images in version 3 and version 4, you can refer to the following table in the document:

Table 1. Supported Docker base images that Vulnerability Advisor 3 checks for vulnerable packages

Docker base image | Supported versions | Source of security notices
--- | --- | ---
Alpine | All stable versions with vendor security support. | [Git - Alpine Linux](https://gitlab.alpinelinux.org/) and [CVE](https://cve.mitre.org/data/downloads/index.html).
CentOS | Version 7 | [CentOS announce archives](https://lists.centos.org/pipermail/centos-announce/) and [CentOS CR announce archives](https://lists.centos.org/pipermail/centos-cr-announce/).
Debian | All stable versions with vendor security support or long-term support. | [Debian security announcements](https://lists.debian.org/debian-security-announce/) and [Debian LTS Security Information](https://www.debian.org/lts/security/).
GoogleContainerTools distroless | All stable versions with vendor security support. | [GoogleContainerTools distroless](https://github.com/GoogleContainerTools/distroless)
Red Hat® Enterprise Linux® (RHEL) | RHEL/UBI 7, RHEL/UBI 8, and RHEL/UBI 9 | [Red Hat Security Data API](https://access.redhat.com/labsinfo/securitydataapi).
Ubuntu | All stable versions with vendor security support.

rewritten_query: What if I want to create encrypted image?
agent_response:
If you want to create an encrypted image, you can follow these steps provided in the document:

1. Determine your own passphrase to use for encrypting your image. This passphrase will be required when you import the image to IBM Cloud VPC.
2. Verify your current qcow2 custom image using the `qemu-img info` command.
3. Create a new, empty qcow2 file of the exact same size and encrypt it with LUKS encryption using the passphrase you chose earlier.
4. Convert your qcow2 image to the encrypted image using the `qemu-img convert` command.

Once you have created your encrypted image, you can upload it to IBM Cloud Object Storage and import it to IBM Cloud VPC. However, keep in mind that Vulnerability Advisor will not be able to scan encrypted images for security issues.

rewritten_query: Can you clarify IBM Cloud® Container Registry you are mentioning here?
agent_response: Yes, of course! IBM Cloud® Container Registry is a managed, multi-tenant private image registry service provided by IBM Cloud. It allows users to store and share container images with other users in the same IBM Cloud account. This service is built on Red Hat® OpenShift Container Platform and is integrated with IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service. The registry is highly available, scalable, and encrypted, and is hosted and managed by IBM. Users can store, access, and manage their container images using the IBM Cloud Container Registry service. This service is required if using Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud. It provides a centralized repository for container images that can be used to deploy applications on IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service clusters. It also offers features such as image scanning for vulnerabilities and automated policy enforcement for compliance.

what is difference between Vulnerability Advisor version 3 and version 4?
Vulnerability Advisor version 4 has some differences in behavior compared to version 3.
For instance, in version 4, the image is indexed the first time it is pushed, and the vulnerability assessment is calculated every time Vulnerability Advisor is queried about that image.
Additionally, the supported Docker base images that Vulnerability Advisor checks for vulnerable packages have been updated in version 4.
However, version 4 only supports releases of platforms that are currently supported by the vendor of that platform.

For a detailed comparison of the supported Docker base images in version 3 and version 4, you can refer to the following table in the document:

Table 1.

Supported Docker base images that Vulnerability Advisor 3 checks for vulnerable packages

Docker base image | Supported versions | Source of security notices
--- | --- | ---
Alpine | All stable versions with vendor security support.
| [Git - Alpine Linux](https://gitlab.alpinelinux.org/) and [CVE](https://cve.mitre.org/data/downloads/index.html).
CentOS | Version 7 | [CentOS announce archives](https://lists.centos.org/pipermail/centos-announce/) and [CentOS CR announce archives](https://lists.centos.org/pipermail/centos-cr-announce/).
Debian | All stable versions with vendor security support or long-term support.
| [Debian security announcements](https://lists.debian.org/debian-security-announce/) and [Debian LTS Security Information](https://www.debian.org/lts/security/).
GoogleContainerTools distroless | All stable versions with vendor security support.

| [GoogleContainerTools distroless](https://github.com/GoogleContainerTools/distroless)
Red Hat® Enterprise Linux® (RHEL) | RHEL/UBI 7, RHEL/UBI 8, and RHEL/UBI 9 | [Red Hat Security Data API](https://access.redhat.com/labsinfo/securitydataapi).
Ubuntu | All stable versions with vendor security support.

What if I want to create encrypted image since Vulnerability Advisor can not scan it?

If you want to create an encrypted image, you can follow these steps provided in the document:

1.
Determine your own passphrase to use for encrypting your image.
This passphrase will be required when you import the image to IBM Cloud VPC.
Verify your current qcow2 custom image using the `qemu-img info` command.
Create a new, empty qcow2 file of the exact same size and encrypt it with LUKS encryption using the passphrase you chose earlier.
Convert your qcow2 image to the encrypted image using the `qemu-img convert` command.
Once you have created your encrypted image, you can upload it to IBM Cloud Object Storage and import it to IBM Cloud VPC.
However, keep in mind that Vulnerability Advisor will not be able to scan encrypted images for security issues.
can you clarify IBM Cloud® Container Registry you are mentioning here?
Yes, of course!
IBM Cloud® Container Registry is a managed, multi-tenant private image registry service provided by IBM Cloud.
It allows users to store and share container images with other users in the same IBM Cloud account.
This service is built on Red Hat® OpenShift Container Platform and is integrated with IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service.
The registry is highly available, scalable, and encrypted, and is hosted and managed by IBM.
Users can store, access, and manage their container images using the IBM Cloud Container Registry service.
This service is required if using Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud.
It provides a centralized repository for container images that can be used to deploy applications on IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service clusters.
It also offers features such as image scanning for vulnerabilities and automated policy enforcement for compliance.

agent_response:
A namespace in IBM Cloud Container Registry is a way to separate images and resources. To set up namespaces, you can follow these general steps:

1. Log in to the IBM Cloud console.
2. Navigate to the IBM Cloud Container Registry service.
3. Click on "Namespaces" in the left-hand menu.
4. Click on "Create namespace" and enter the desired name for your namespace.
5. Set the desired resource group, location, and other options for your namespace.
6. Click "Create" to create the namespace.

Once the namespace is created, you can start pushing and pulling images to and from that namespace. You can also set up access policies for the namespace to control who can access the images in the namespace.

For more detailed instructions and information, you can refer to the IBM Cloud Container Registry documentation on creating and managing namespaces.

rewritten_query: What are the benefits of Red Hat OpenShift virtualization?
agent_response:
Based on the provided document, Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud offers several benefits for developers and organizations. Here are some of them:

1. **Fast and secure containerization and deployment**: Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud provides a fast and secure way for developers to containerize and deploy enterprise workloads in Kubernetes clusters. It offers consistency and flexibility for the development lifecycle operations.
2. **Scalability**: Red Hat OpenShift workloads can scale across IBM’s global footprint of data centers and multizone regions, allowing organizations to uniformly monitor, log, and secure apps.
3. **Access to high-value IBM Cloud services and middleware**: With IBM managing the service, organizations can focus on innovating with high-value IBM Cloud services and middleware, such as AI and analytics. They also have access to Red Hat packaged open-source tools, including their favorite app runtimes, frameworks, databases, and more.
4. **Choice of container platform provider**: Organizations can deploy clusters with Red Hat OpenShift or community Kubernetes installed as the container platform orchestrator. They can also choose the developer experience that fits their company or run workloads across both Red Hat OpenShift or community Kubernetes clusters.
5. **Single view and management experience**: IBM Cloud provides built-in integrations from the IBM Cloud console to the Kubernetes dashboard or Red Hat OpenShift web console, offering a single view and management experience of all Red Hat OpenShift or community Kubernetes clusters.

For healthcare providers, Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud offers secure compute on isolated bare metal, easy spin-up of clusters for faster development, migration from virtual machines, and data sharing in cloud databases. By containerizing their SaaS systems and putting them in the cloud, healthcare providers can reduce IT operations, maintenance, and energy costs while delivering better customer service. Additionally, developers can experiment easily with Node.js SDK, push changes to Development and Test systems, and deliver incremental updates to their users, daily or even more frequently.

rewritten_query: Could you provide more information about the solutions offered by Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud, particularly for healthcare providers?
agent_response: Based on the documents provided, Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud offers solutions for securely hosting and sharing disease data for a research nonprofit. The nonprofit can create a division dedicated to solutions for their researchers, which includes INGEST apps to ingest research data, ANONYMIZE apps to anonymize the data, and ANALYZE apps to analyze the data. Researchers need to affiliate with a regional cluster, and apps ingest, transform, and anonymize the data. The anonymized data can then be synced across regional clusters or shipped to a centralized data store, and processed by using machine learning (ML) like PyTorch on bare metal worker nodes that provide GPUs. IBM Cloudant is used at each regional cluster to store researchers' rich data documents and can be queried and processed as needed. Additionally, the provider can adopt IBM Garage Method practices to implement an agile and iterative delivery process that supports modern DevOps practices like CI/CD.

The documents provided contain information on how to prepare for creating clusters in the context of IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service. It is important to note that the specific steps and requirements might vary depending on whether you are creating a VPC Gen2 or classic cluster. Here are some key points to consider:

1. Prepare your account: This includes creating a billable account, setting up an API key with infrastructure permissions, making sure you have Administrator access in IBM Cloud IAM, planning resource groups, and setting up account networking.
2. Decide on your cluster setup: This includes planning cluster network and HA setup, estimating costs, and allowing network traffic through a firewall if applicable.
3. Create your cluster: You can create your VPC Gen2 or classic cluster by following the steps in the IBM Cloud console or CLI.

rewritten_query: Should we consider using Carthage for installing the mobile SDK?
agent_response:
To install the mobile SDK using Carthage, create a file named Cartfile in the project directory for your app and add the following line in the file:

github "openwhisk/openwhisk-client-swift.git" > 0.3.0 Or latest version

Then, from the command line, type carthage update --platform ios. Carthage will download and build the SDK, create a directory named Carthage in the project directory for your app, and put an OpenWhisk.framework file inside Carthage/build/iOS. After that, add the OpenWhisk.framework file to the embedded frameworks in your Xcode project.

If you encounter any warnings during the build process, you can fix them by either changing the setting Use Legacy Swift Language Version to no in the Pods project, or by adding the following post-installation instructions at the end of your Podfile:

post\_install do |installer|
installer.pods\_project.targets.each do |target|
target.build\_configurations.each do |config|
config.build\_settings['SWIFT\_VERSION'] = '4.0'
end
end
end

Keep in mind that the mobile SDK is not supported for IAM-based namespaces, and you should use a Cloud Foundry-based namespace instead.

agent_response:
Here is an example of source code using the ENPushDestination dependency in Swift:

1. First, import the ENPushDestination framework at the top of your Swift file:

```swift
import ENPushDestination
```

2. Next, create an instance of the ENPushDestination class to initialize the dependency:

```swift
let pushDestination = ENPushDestination()
```

3. You can then use the methods and properties of the ENPushDestination class to implement push notifications functionality in your app.

For example, you might use the `configure(withAPIKey:)` method to configure the SDK with an API key, and the `addDestination(with:)` method to add a push notification destination:

```swift
pushDestination.configure(withAPIKey: "your_api_key")
pushDestination.addDestination(with: "your_destination_config")
```

Keep in mind that you need to replace `"your_api_key"` and `"your_destination_config"` with your actual API key and destination configuration. The exact method calls and properties you use will depend on your specific use case and requirements.

Also, note that the mobile SDK is not supported for IAM-based namespaces, and you should use a Cloud Foundry-based namespace instead.

I'll provide you with a step-by-step process to install the ENPushDestination dependency using Carthage as you mentioned earlier:

1.

Create a file named `Cartfile` in the project directory for your app, and add the following line in the file:

```
github "IBM/event-notifications-destination-ios-sdk" > 0.0.1
```

2.

Run the following command in the terminal from the project directory to build the dependencies and frameworks:

```
carthage update --platform iOS
```

3.

After running the command, Carthage will download and build the SDK, create a directory named `Carthage` in the project directory for your app, and put an `ENPushDestination.framework` file inside `Carthage/build/iOS`.
Add the `ENPushDestination.framework` file to the embedded frameworks in your Xcode project.

If you encounter any warnings during the build process, you can fix them by either changing the setting `Use Legacy Swift Language Version` to `no` in the Pods project, or by adding the following post-installation instructions at the end of your Podfile:

```ruby
post_install do |installer|
  installer.pods_project.targets.each do |target|
    target.build_configurations.each do |config|
      config.build_settings['SWIFT_VERSION'] = '4.0'
    end
  end
end
```

Keep in mind that the mobile SDK is not supported for IAM-based namespaces, and you should use a Cloud Foundry-based namespace instead.

Here is an example of source code using the ENPushDestination dependency in Swift:

1.

First, import the ENPushDestination framework at the top of your Swift file:

```swift
import ENPushDestination
```

2.

Next, create an instance of the ENPushDestination class to initialize the dependency:

```swift
let pushDestination = ENPushDestination()
```

3.
You can then use the methods and properties of the ENPushDestination class to implement push notifications functionality in your app.

For example, you might use the `configure(withAPIKey:)` method to configure the SDK with an API key, and the `addDestination(with:)` method to add a push notification destination:

```swift
pushDestination.configure(withAPIKey: "your_api_key")
pushDestination.addDestination(with: "your_destination_config")
```

Keep in mind that you need to replace `"your_api_key"` and `"your_destination_config"` with your actual API key and destination configuration.
The exact method calls and properties you use will depend on your specific use case and requirements.
Also, note that the mobile SDK is not supported for IAM-based namespaces, and you should use a Cloud Foundry-based namespace instead.

rewritten_query: May I configure to work with different installations of Cloud Functions?
agent_response:
Yes, you can configure the SDK to work with different installations of Cloud Functions by using the `baseURL` parameter. For example, you can set `whisk.baseURL = "http://localhost:8080"` to use an installation running at `http://localhost:8080`. If you do not specify the `baseURL`, the mobile SDK uses the instance running at `[https://us-south.functions.cloud.ibm.com](https://us-south.functions.cloud.ibm.com)`.

You can also pass in a custom `NSURLSession` in case you require special network handling, such as with self-signed certificates.

Additionally, you can configure the SDK to return metadata of the entire response object, including the HTTP response status code, by setting `whisk.verboseReplies = true`.

rewritten_query: What are the instructions to do it using Carthage?
agent_response:
To install the IBM Cloud Functions mobile SDK using Carthage, follow these steps:

1. Create a file in the project directory for your app and name it Cartfile.
2. Put the following line in the file: `github "openwhisk/openwhisk-client-swift.git" > 0.3.0 Or latest version`
3. From the command line, type `carthage update --platform ios`.
4. Carthage downloads and builds the SDK, creates a directory that is called Carthage in the project directory for your app, and puts an OpenWhisk.framework file inside Carthage/build/iOS.
5. Add OpenWhisk.framework file to the embedded frameworks in your Xcode project.

For more information on using Carthage, you can refer to the [Carthage getting-started guide](https://github.com/Carthage/Carthage/blob/master/Documentation/GettingStarted.md).

rewritten_query: Can you tell me more about WebSocket API?
agent_response:
Based on the documents you provided, the WebSocket API is used to send two types of parameters: query parameters and message parameters. Query parameters are sent when phone integration connects to the service, while message parameters are sent as part of the JSON data in the request body. The WebSocket API can be used to change the voice of the assistant, enable or disable speech barge-in, and transfer a call to a live agent. When the socket closes with an error, the client receives an informative message of the form {"error":"{message}"} before the socket closes.

rewritten_query: How can I use WebSocket API?
agent_response:
To use the WebSocket API for the IBM Watson Text to Speech service, you first need to establish a connection with the service by calling its /v1/synthesize method over the WebSocket Secure (WSS) protocol. The method should be available at a specific endpoint, which includes the location of your application and the unique identifier of the service instance.

Once the connection is established, you can send input text as a JSON text message over the connection. The WebSocket interface also supports the use of the SSML <mark> element to identify the location of user-specified markers in the audio and can return timing information for all strings of the input text.

The WebSocket interface accepts identical input and produces identical results as the GET and POST /v1/synthesize methods of the HTTP interface.

For more information about using the WebSocket API, you can refer to the API & SDK reference provided in the documents. Additionally, you can consult the WebSocket return codes information in IETF RFC 6455 for more information about the WebSocket protocol.

rewritten_query: I want to secure the phone connection before the integration.
agent_response:
To secure the phone connection before the integration, you can follow these steps:

1. Go to the Advanced options tab in the phone integration settings.
2. Select one or both of the following options:
   - Force secure trunking: This option uses Secure Real-Time Transfer Protocol (SRTP) to secure the audio that is transmitted over the phone.
   - Enable SIP authentication: This option requires SIP digest authentication for all inbound traffic. When this option is selected, the SIP digest user name and password must be configured, and the SIP trunk being used to connect to Assistant must be configured to use only TLS. Note that if you use Twilio as your SIP trunk provider, you cannot enable SIP authentication for outbound SIP trunks to Watson Assistant.

If you are using a SIP trunk from an external provider, you can configure how your assistant interacts with it by going to the SIP trunk tab in the phone integration settings and updating the SIP trunking integration section. Here, you can list the headers that you want your assistant to use by updating the "SIP INVITE headers to extract" option.

To optimize your actions for phone interaction, you can follow these guidelines:

1. Do not include HTML elements in your action responses. To add formatting, use Markdown.
2. Use a search extension to include search results in actions that the phone integration will read. When search results are returned, the phone integration reads the introductory message and then the body of only the first search result. The entire search response must be less than 5,000 characters long. Be sure to test the search results that are returned and curate the data collection that you use as necessary.

can you tell me more about WebSocket API?
Based on the documents you provided, the WebSocket API is used to send two types of parameters: query parameters and message parameters.
Query parameters are sent when phone integration connects to the service, while message parameters are sent as part of the JSON data in the request body.
The WebSocket API can be used to change the voice of the assistant, enable or disable speech barge-in, and transfer a call to a live agent.
When the socket closes with an error, the client receives an informative message of the form {"error":"{message}"} before the socket closes.
For more information about the WebSocket API, you can refer to the Text to Speech API documentation provided in the documents.
Additionally, you can consult the WebSocket return codes information in IETF RFC 6455 and the API & SDK reference for more information about the WebSocket implementations of the SDKs.
how can I use WebSocket API?

To use the WebSocket API for the IBM Watson Text to Speech service, you first need to establish a connection with the service by calling its /v1/synthesize method over the WebSocket Secure (WSS) protocol.
The method should be available at a specific endpoint, which includes the location of your application and the unique identifier of the service instance.
Once the connection is established, you can send input text as a JSON text message over the connection.

The WebSocket interface also supports the use of the SSML <mark> element to identify the location of user-specified markers in the audio and can return timing information for all strings of the input text.
The WebSocket interface accepts identical input and produces identical results as the GET and POST /v1/synthesize methods of the HTTP interface.
For more information about using the WebSocket API, you can refer to the API & SDK reference provided in the documents.
Additionally, you can consult the WebSocket return codes information in IETF RFC 6455 for more information about the WebSocket protocol.

I want to secure the phone connection before the integration

To secure the phone connection before the integration, you can follow these steps:

1.
Go to the Advanced options tab in the phone integration settings.

Select one or both of the following options:
   - Force secure trunking: This option uses Secure Real-Time Transfer Protocol (SRTP) to secure the audio that is transmitted over the phone.
- Enable SIP authentication: This option requires SIP digest authentication for all inbound traffic.
When this option is selected, the SIP digest user name and password must be configured, and the SIP trunk being used to connect to Assistant must be configured to use only TLS.
Note that if you use Twilio as your SIP trunk provider, you cannot enable SIP authentication for outbound SIP trunks to Watson Assistant.

If you are using a SIP trunk from an external provider, you can configure how your assistant interacts with it by going to the SIP trunk tab in the phone integration settings and updating the SIP trunking integration section.

rewritten_query: What if I have call and transfer failures, requiring the use of other third-party providers?
agent_response:
If you experience call and transfer failures, you can configure the phone integration to transfer the caller to a human agent if the phone connection fails for any reason. You can specify a SIP or telephone URI for a general call queue that can redirect requests to other queues. Additionally, you can configure a call failure message and a transfer failure message that the assistant will say to a caller if the call transfer to a live agent fails. If you choose to leave a call connected despite a transfer failure, Watson Assistant will initiate a new turn to determine the next step. It's important that the Assistant be configured with an Action or webhook that can handle this scenario.

If you need to use third-party providers for handling call and transfer failures, you can consider using a SIP trunking provider that can support disaster recovery by configuring two separate SIP trunks, one for each region. The SIP INVITE failure timeouts should be set low enough to avoid long call setup latencies when a failover is occurring.

For handling partial service outages within the region, Watson Assistant can be configured to respond to a SIP INVITE with a SIP 500 (service unavailable) message if an outage is detected during call setup instead of transferring a call to a live agent. This can redirect the call to another zone or region. However, to enable this 500 error response capability for a specific Watson Assistant instance, you need to make a request to IBM.

It's important to plan for both full and partial service outages and start with a strategy for detecting and failing over to the passive backup region when a complete regional outage is detected. After this is in place, a strategy can be implemented to deal with partial outages, which should cover the vast majority of failure conditions that can occur with a phone integration deployment.

agent_response: An IAM (Identity and Access Management) credential is a type of secret that is used to authenticate and authorize access to IBM Cloud resources and services. It typically includes information such as an API key, user name, password, and other service-specific parameters. IAM credentials can be managed and created using the IBM Cloud IAM service, and they can be used to control and monitor access to IBM Cloud resources and services. They can also be automatically rotated to enhance security.

rewritten_query: Can I track my users?
agent_response:
Based on the documents provided, you can track user activities and events in your IBM Cloud account using the IBM Cloud Activity Tracker service. This service allows you to monitor how users and applications interact with your IBM Cloud account, the IBM Cloud catalog, private catalogs, and IBM Cloud Identity and Access Management (IAM).

You can track various events, including account management events (such as managing an account, adding or removing users, and creating organizations), IAM events (such as managing access groups, creating and deleting service IDs, and logging in to IBM Cloud), and catalog management events (such as viewing or updating catalogs and creating, updating, viewing, or deleting products).

For IAM events, you must create an instance of the Activity Tracker service in the Frankfurt (eu-de) region to start tracking IAM events.

To track runtime authentication events, you can integrate Activity Tracker and App ID, which allows you to track, manage, and analyze authentication events that are performed by your app users at runtime.

For more information, you can refer to the following links:

* Activity Tracker: <https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/activity-tracker?topic=activity-tracker-getting-startedgetting-started>
* IAM events: <https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/activity-tracker?topic=activity-tracker-at_events_iam>
* Auditing events for IBM Analytics Engine serverless instances: <https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/AnalyticsEngine?topic=AnalyticsEngine-at_events-serverless>
* Track, manage, and analyze authentication events at runtime: <https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/appid?topic=appid-at-eventsat-monitor-runtime>

Regarding tracking individual user activities, you can use the Activity Tracker service to monitor events and activities performed by users in your IBM Cloud account. However, the documents do not provide specific information about tracking individual users beyond this.

extracted_sentences: Is Dynamic secret better than Static secret?
The documents do not provide a direct comparison between dynamic and static secrets in terms of which one is better.
Instead, they describe the differences between the two types of secrets.

Dynamic secrets have their expiration date and time enforced when their secret data is read or accessed, while static secrets have their expiration date and time enforced at secret creation or rotation time.
The choice between dynamic and static secrets would depend on the specific use case and security requirements.
Which one protects more from vulnerabilities?
The documents do not provide information on which type of secret, dynamic or static, offers more protection against vulnerabilities.
The security of a secret depends on various factors such as its management, storage, and access control, rather than just the type.
It is recommended to follow best practices for secrets management and data protection to ensure the security of sensitive information.
Do they both rotate secrets?
Yes, both dynamic and static secrets can have their data rotated.
For dynamic secrets, the expiration date and time are enforced when their secret data is read or accessed.
For static secrets, the expiration date and time are enforced at secret creation or rotation time.
The documents also mention the concept of automatic rotation, which is supported for some types of secrets, including IAM credentials and imported certificates.
However, the documents do not provide specific information on how rotation is performed for each type of secret.
What is an IAM credential?
An IAM (Identity and Access Management) credential is a type of secret that is used to authenticate and authorize access to IBM Cloud resources and services.
It typically includes information such as an API key, user name, password, and other service-specific parameters.
IAM credentials can be managed and created using the IBM Cloud IAM service, and they can be used to control and monitor access to IBM Cloud resources and services.
They can also be automatically rotated to enhance security.
Can I track my users?
Based on the documents provided, you can track user activities and events in your IBM Cloud account using the IBM Cloud Activity Tracker service.
This service allows you to monitor how users and applications interact with your IBM Cloud account, the IBM Cloud catalog, private catalogs, and IBM Cloud Identity and Access Management (IAM).

For IAM events, you must create an instance of the Activity Tracker service in the Frankfurt (eu-de) region to start tracking IAM events.

rewritten_query: Explain Spark.
agent_response: Apache Spark is an open-source, distributed computing system used for big data processing and analytics. It provides an interface for programming entire clusters with implicit data parallelism and fault tolerance. Spark supports a wide range of tools, libraries, and frameworks for data processing, including SQL, streaming, machine learning, and graph processing. It can be run on various platforms, such as Hadoop, Kubernetes, Mesos, and standalone, and it integrates with different data storage systems, such as HDFS, Cassandra, and S3. Spark also supports various programming languages, such as Python, Scala, Java, and R. It is commonly used for use cases such as data warehousing, machine learning, graph processing, and real-time streaming.

rewritten_query: Could you tell me more about the Hive metastore client?
agent_response:
The Hive metastore client is a component that allows Apache Spark to interact with the Hive metastore service, which is a centralized repository for metadata related to Hive tables and partitions. The Hive metastore client is used to read and write metadata information to the Hive metastore service, enabling Spark to perform various operations such as query optimization, data serialization, and error handling.

To configure the Hive metastore client in Spark, you need to set the appropriate properties in the Spark configuration, such as the Hive metastore URI, truststore password, and client authentication mode. The Hive-compatible client can be downloaded from the IBM SQL Query Cloud and placed in a directory of your Spark cluster that is not on the classpath.

Additionally, you can use the IBM Cloud Object Storage (COS) connector to register the required COS path used in your application and add endpoints for all buckets. This allows Spark to read and write data from and to COS using the Hive metastore client.

original_query: Can you summarize the differences between good bots and bad bots?
rewritten_query: Can you summarize the differences between good bots and bad bots?
agent_response: Good bots and bad bots differ in their intent and the rules they follow. Good bots perform helpful services, such as customer service chatbots, search engine crawlers, and performance monitoring bots. They look for and abide by the rules outlined in a website's robots.txt file. On the other hand, bad bots misuse online products or services, ranging from malicious acts like breaking into user accounts to steal data, to less harmful yet annoying behaviors like buying concert tickets online to assist scalpers. Malicious bots do not follow the honor system of checking a website's robots.txt file before accessing it, necessitating bot management tools for identification and control.

rewritten_query: Could you describe the characteristics of the CIS bot?
agent_response: IBM Cloud® Internet Services (CIS) bot features include JavaScript detections using Google's Picasso fingerprinting technique, which gathers general data about the machines reaching CIS. This detection technique helps CIS classify traffic as automated or human by collecting information about user agents, HTTP request headers, and other device characteristics. BotScoreSrc: Not Computed and a score of 0 are relevant to Picasso JavaScript Fingerprinting requests, which are exempt from being blocked by any firewall rules. JavaScript is only injected in response to requests for HTML pages or page views, excluding AJAX calls. API and mobile app traffic is unaffected. Additionally, code is not injected again until its 30-minute session life expires.

rewritten_query: How does CIS manage bots?
agent_response: IBM Cloud® Internet Services (CIS) manages bots by collecting data from requests flowing through its network every day, and using this data, powered by Cloudflare's machine learning and behavior analysis, to identify likely bot activity. CIS can provide you with information on how to allow or disallow specific bot traffic using Firewall Rules. CIS Bot Management uses various detection mechanisms, including machine learning, heuristics engine, behavioral analysis, verified bots, JS fingerprinting, and the use of a robots.txt file to set up a honeypot to identify and block bad bots. CIS also offers JavaScript detections using Google's Picasso fingerprinting technique to gather general data about the machines reaching CIS and help classify traffic as automated or human.

Good bots and bad bots differ in their intent and the rules they follow.
Good bots perform helpful services, such as customer service chatbots, search engine crawlers, and performance monitoring bots.
They look for and abide by the rules outlined in a website's robots.txt file.

On the other hand, bad bots misuse online products or services, ranging from malicious acts like breaking into user accounts to steal data, to less harmful yet annoying behaviors like buying concert tickets online to assist scalpers.
Malicious bots do not follow the honor system of checking a website's robots.txt file before accessing it, necessitating bot management tools for identification and control.

IBM Cloud® Internet Services (CIS) bot features include JavaScript detections using Google's Picasso fingerprinting technique, which gathers general data about the machines reaching CIS.
This detection technique helps CIS classify traffic as automated or human by collecting information about user agents, HTTP request headers, and other device characteristics.

rewritten_query: How can I update the machine learning models used in CIS bot management?
agent_response:
To update machine learning models in the context of the provided document, follow these steps:

1. Log in to the CIS and select your account and domain.
2. Go to Security > Bots.
3. Select Configure Bot Management.
4. Enable auto-updates to the machine learning model.

Enabling auto-updates immediately upgrades you to the latest version. You can toggle the button off within 24 hours to revert to the previous version, and contact support for further changes after 24 hours. If you are on an older machine learning model, there will be a score change to requests scored by the machine learning source instantly. If you are already on the latest model, the changes will show only after a new machine learning model becomes the global default. You will be notified prior to a new machine learning model becoming the global default.

When updating machine learning models, it's important to note that not updating to the latest version means using a model that is no longer maintained or monitored by the engineering team, which can lead to degraded scoring accuracy due to changes in internet traffic and emerging trends.

In a different text, the process of making modifications to a model while training and modifying the type system without losing human annotator work is described. However, this process does not directly refer to updating a machine learning model with new data or improved algorithms.

rewritten_query: Create a machine learning model, how do I do that?
agent_response:
Yes, you can create a machine learning model using IBM Watson® Knowledge Studio. Here are the steps to follow:

1. Log in to Knowledge Studio as the administrator.
2. Click on "Machine Learning Model" followed by "Performance" and then select "Train and evaluate".
3. Select all the document sets and click on "Train & Evaluate". Training might take more than ten minutes or even hours, depending on the number of human annotations and the number of words in all the documents.
4. After the machine learning model is trained, you can export it from the Version page, or you can view detailed information about its performance by clicking the Detailed Statistics links that are located above each of the graphs on the Performance page.

Note that only documents that became ground truth through approval or adjudication can be used to train the machine learning model. For more information about the machine learning model, see [Training the machine learning model](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/watson-knowledge-studio?topic=watson-knowledge-studio-train-ml) and [Analyzing machine learning model performance](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/watson-knowledge-studio?topic=watson-knowledge-studio-evaluate-ml).

rewritten_query: Can bots acquire private user information?
agent_response: Yes, some types of bad bots are designed to extract private information from users. They can use various techniques such as phishing, keylogging, or exploiting software vulnerabilities to steal sensitive data like usernames, passwords, credit card numbers, and other personal information. It's essential to have proper bot management and security measures in place to protect user data and prevent unauthorized access. Encrypting sensitive customer information and including it as part of the JWT user payload can help prevent unauthorized access to this data. Additionally, authenticating users and specifying a unique ID for each customer can further enhance security.

rewritten_query: Can you explain what a secret is in this context?

extracted_sentences: Can you summarize the differences between good bots and bad bots?
Good bots and bad bots differ in their intent and the rules they follow.
Good bots perform helpful services, such as customer service chatbots, search engine crawlers, and performance monitoring bots.
They look for and abide by the rules outlined in a website's robots.txt file.

On the other hand, bad bots misuse online products or services, ranging from malicious acts like breaking into user accounts to steal data, to less harmful yet annoying behaviors like buying concert tickets online to assist scalpers.
Malicious bots do not follow the honor system of checking a website's robots.txt file before accessing it, necessitating bot management tools for identification and control.
What are the features in the CIS bot?
IBM Cloud® Internet Services (CIS) bot features include JavaScript detections using Google's Picasso fingerprinting technique, which gathers general data about the machines reaching CIS.
This detection technique helps CIS classify traffic as automated or human by collecting information about user agents, HTTP request headers, and other device characteristics.
BotScoreSrc: Not Computed and a score of 0 are relevant to Picasso JavaScript Fingerprinting requests, which are exempt from being blocked by any firewall rules.
JavaScript is only injected in response to requests for HTML pages or page views, excluding AJAX calls.
API and mobile app traffic is unaffected.
Additionally, code is not injected again until its 30-minute session life expires.
How does CIS manage bots?

IBM Cloud® Internet Services (CIS) manages bots by collecting data from requests flowing through its network every day, and using this data, powered by Cloudflare's machine learning and behavior analysis, to identify likely bot activity.
CIS can provide you with information on how to allow or disallow specific bot traffic using Firewall Rules.

CIS Bot Management uses various detection mechanisms, including machine learning, heuristics engine, behavioral analysis, verified bots, JS fingerprinting, and the use of a robots.txt file to set up a honeypot to identify and block bad bots.
CIS also offers JavaScript detections using Google's Picasso fingerprinting technique to gather general data about the machines reaching CIS and help classify traffic as automated or human.
How can I update machine leaning models?

To update machine learning models in the context of the provided document, follow these steps:

1.
Log in to the CIS and select your account and domain.
Go to Security > Bots.
Select Configure Bot Management.
Enable auto-updates to the machine learning model.
Enabling auto-updates immediately upgrades you to the latest version.
You can toggle the button off within 24 hours to revert to the previous version, and contact support for further changes after 24 hours.
If you are on an older machine learning model, there will be a score change to requests scored by the machine learning source instantly.
If you are already on the latest model, the changes will show only after a new machine learning model becomes the global default.
You will be notified prior to a new machine learning model becoming the global default.

When updating machine learning models, it's important to note that not updating to the latest version means using a model that is no longer maintained or monitored by the engineering team, which can lead to degraded scoring accuracy due to changes in internet traffic and emerging trends.
In a different text, the process of making modifications to a model while training and modifying the type system without losing human annotator work is described.
However, this process does not directly refer to updating a machine learning model with new data or improved algorithms.
Can I create a machine learning model and how should I do that?
Yes, you can create a machine learning model using IBM Watson® Knowledge Studio.

Here are the steps to follow:

1.
Log in to Knowledge Studio as the administrator.
Click on "Machine Learning Model" followed by "Performance" and then select "Train and evaluate".
Select all the document sets and click on "Train & Evaluate".
Training might take more than ten minutes or even hours, depending on the number of human annotations and the number of words in all the documents.

After the machine learning model is trained, you can export it from the Version page, or you can view detailed information about its performance by clicking the Detailed Statistics links that are located above each of the graphs on the Performance page.
Note that only documents that became ground truth through approval or adjudication can be used to train the machine learning model.

For more information about the machine learning model, see [Training the machine learning model](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/watson-knowledge-studio?topic=watson-knowledge-studio-train-ml) and [Analyzing machine learning model performance](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/watson-knowledge-studio?topic=watson-knowledge-studio-evaluate-ml).
Speaking about bots again, can they get private information from the user
Yes, some types of bad bots are designed to extract private information from users.

They can use various techniques such as phishing, keylogging, or exploiting software vulnerabilities to steal sensitive data like usernames, passwords, credit card numbers, and other personal information.
It's essential to have proper bot management and security measures in place to protect user data and prevent unauthorized access.
Encrypting sensitive customer information and including it as part of the JWT user payload can help prevent unauthorized access to this data.
Additionally, authenticating users and specifying a unique ID for each customer can further enhance security.

rewritten_query: How can I protect my privacy?
agent_response:
To protect your privacy, you can follow these guidelines:

1. Limit sharing personal data: Be cautious about sharing your personal information, such as your name, address, or phone number, online or with unknown entities. Only provide such information when necessary and trustworthy.
2. Use strong passwords and multi-factor authentication: Create complex and unique passwords for each account and enable multi-factor authentication when available.
3. Regularly update software: Keep your operating system, web browsers, and other software up-to-date to protect against known vulnerabilities.
4. Encrypt sensitive information: Encrypt sensitive data, like credit card numbers and personal documents, to protect it during transmission and storage.
5. Enable privacy-enhancing features: Utilize privacy-enhancing features, such as Do Not Track and privacy-focused browser extensions, to minimize data collection.
6. Be cautious with links and downloads: Avoid clicking on suspicious links or downloading unverified software, as they could lead to phishing attacks or malware infections.
7. Use a VPN: Use a virtual private network (VPN) to encrypt your internet connection and protect your data from eavesdropping.
8. Regularly review privacy policies: Read and understand privacy policies of online services you use to know how your data is collected, used, and protected.
9. Limit social media sharing: Be mindful of the information you share on social media, as it can be used to infer personal details and potentially exploited.
10. Educate yourself: Stay informed about the latest privacy threats and best practices to ensure you're well-equipped to protect your personal information.

By following these guidelines, you can maintain your privacy and minimize the risk of unauthorized access to your personal information.

original_query: How do I build my client application using dialogue nodes?
rewritten_query: How do I build my client application using dialogue nodes?
agent_response:
To build your client application using dialogue nodes, you can follow these steps:

1. Complete follow-on tutorials that build more advanced dialogs. You can add more dialog nodes to design complex conversational exchanges (Building a complex dialog) and learn techniques for getting customers to share information that the assistant needs before it can provide a useful response (Adding a node with slots).

2. When you're ready to deploy your assistant, see Deploying for instructions on how to integrate it with websites or channels, such as Slack, that your customers already use.

Please note that the provided document assumes you have a basic understanding of dialog nodes and how to use them. If you need more information on dialog nodes, you can check out the IBM Cloud documentation or other available resources.

rewritten_query: Could you tell me what worker nodes are?
agent_response: Worker nodes, in the context of IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service, refer to the virtual machines that your cluster manages. These worker nodes are dedicated to you and are not shared with other IBM customers, although the underlying hardware is shared with other customers. You manage the worker nodes through the automation tools provided by IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service, such as the API, CLI, or console. They include the same components as described in the Classic architecture and run on Ubuntu 18.04 x86_64 or 16.04 x86_64 (deprecated) for Community Kubernetes worker nodes. For more information, you can refer to the document on Virtual machines.

rewritten_query: Could you tell me about VPC clusters?
agent_response: VPC clusters, in the context of IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service, refer to a cluster where the worker nodes are attached to VPC subnets and assigned private IP addresses. These clusters are not connected to the public network, which instead is accessed through a public gateway, floating IP, or VPN gateway. VPC clusters provide an isolated environment for workloads to run within the public cloud, and you can use the same VPC for multiple clusters or create a VPC for each cluster. For more information, you can refer to the document on Overview of VPC networking in IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service.

rewritten_query: How to create a cluster?
agent_response:
To create a cluster in IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service, you can follow these general steps:

1. Prepare your account to create clusters by creating a billable account, setting up an API key with infrastructure permissions, making sure you have Administrator access in IBM Cloud IAM, planning resource groups, and setting up account networking.
2. Decide on your cluster setup, including planning cluster network and HA setup, estimating costs, and allowing network traffic through a firewall if applicable.
3. Create your VPC Gen2 or classic cluster by following the steps in the IBM Cloud console or CLI.

Note that the specific steps may vary based on whether you are creating a VPC Gen2 or classic cluster. Also, if you are creating a cluster at the account level, the account administrator needs to make certain preparations.

For more details, you can refer to the "Preparing to create clusters" documentation in IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service.

rewritten_query: What are the charges for VPC?
agent_response:
Pricing for VPC infrastructure varies based on regional location and sustained usage. This information applies to VPC worker nodes only. When you create a cluster on VPC infrastructure, the worker nodes might incur an uplift charge that varies by the multizone location that you create the cluster in. The uplift charge is a percentage (%) of the hourly rate (r), and is added to the hourly rate of the worker node. The total hourly rate cost for a worker node can be calculated as r + (r × %). For more information on specific regional uplift charges, see [Regional pricing for VPC](https://cloud.ibm.com/vpc-ext/provision/vs). Additionally, for virtual server instances that are billed at an hourly rate, discounted prices depend on how long the instance runs during the billing month. For more information, see [Sustained usage discounts on IBM Cloud Virtual Servers for VPC](https://cloud.ibm.com/vpc-ext/provision/vs).

Regarding the charge for IBM Cloud Schematics templates, the provided document does not contain specific information about the cost of IBM Cloud Schematics templates. IBM Cloud Schematics Workspaces are provided at no cost, but when you apply your Terraform template in IBM Cloud, you are charged for the IBM Cloud resources described in your Terraform template. The cost of these resources can vary based on the specific services and resources you choose to use. You should review available service plans and pricing information for each resource you are about to create.
